data.title: Click on error icons in status bar should toggle error list
data.body:
Click on the error icons in the status bar - notice error list poping up.
Click on the error icons again - I would expect the error list hides, thus the error icons in status bar behave as a toggle - similar to how the debug console icon behaves in the debug viewlet.

Just my expectation.
@stevencl feedback welcome

data.title: Error list: screen cheese with filter
data.body:
Click on the filter icon twice, notice blue outline is not fully outlined - screen cheese

![screen shot 2016-06-02 at 15 00 08](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/15745580/cacb8830-28d2-11e6-9ddf-635ee8be019b.png)

data.title: Clicking on the error does not pass focus to editor if editor already open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: alpha
- OS Version: os x

Steps to Reproduce:
1. have some errors, open error list
2. click on the error - notice how the focus nicely moves to the editor
3. click on the same error again - editor looses focus

I would expect that the behavior is the same if I click first, second or third time...
The issue is that the focus is not passed to editor if that editor is already opened

data.title: Duplicate current line feature
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Debian Jessie

Hello,

I did not foud this usefull feature inside the user shortcut parameter: duplicate the current line
Using any jetbrains IDE I am used to do this with this shortcut: ctrl+d

Lets see if I am the only one who wants this feature inside vscode or if it is worth it to implement it.

data.title: Showing only errors message superfluous
data.body:
I believe that the 'showing only errors' message is unnecessery - we should have a nice toggle icon which would make it clear what is being shown.
We also do not have this pattern (to write what is being filtered) anywhere else (search / find widget) 

![screen shot 2016-06-02 at 12 54 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/15742776/4088c716-28c1-11e6-873e-c629da826c98.png)

data.title: Clicking outside error list focuses the tree and produces an ugly blue outline
data.body:
Clicks outside the error list should simply be ignored.
Currently the error list tree gets focused which as a result has an ugly blue line

![screen shot 2016-06-02 at 12 53 32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/15742737/09cf98a8-28c1-11e6-9651-eb1343a5b3e2.png)

data.title: Improve wording on workspace with no errors
data.body:
![screen shot 2016-06-02 at 12 45 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/15742549/e75d624c-28bf-11e6-947b-34701a522a29.png)

'Clear' for me does not mean without errors. We need a better term here. Maybe something like
'No errors have been detected in the workspace so far'

You are also missing a dot at the end,

data.title: Operating System Specific Properties in launch.json
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1873:
- [x] Windows - @alexandrudima 
- [x] OS X - @jrieken
- [x] Linux - @aeschli 

By request from users #1873
We now support specifying OS specific properties in `launch.json`. Configure your `launch.json` to inlcude OS specific properties, start debugging and verify:
- OS specific properties on that platform take priority over top level properties.
- OS specific properties on a different platform simply get ignored
- Variable substitution works for OS specific properties (e.g ${workspaceRoot} gets replaced)

data.title: VSCode does not format HTML template elements
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.1.1 - OS Version: Windows 10 I figured out that the built-in formatter does nothing when applied to an HTML template element. As far as I see it is really the template tag and all it's content that is completely ignored by the formatter. Other HTML files are formatted properly. When using modern component-based frameworks like Aurelia, you're writing nothing else than templates and for me auto-formatting is indispensable. Steps to reproduce: 1. create a .html file 2. paste in an example template with messed up indentation like: ``` ``` 3. Press _Alt+Shift+F_ to format the file

data.title: Reveal in File Tree as Menu-Option/Shortcut

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0

It would be a great feature to have a right click menu option on a "Working File"-file to reveal a file in the file tree, as well as a shortcut for the same.
This is essential, if you deactivate the `explorer.autoReveal` feature. 

I do not want to always (aka. automaticly) reveal a file in the filetree. But sometimes, currently I can not do so.

data.title: Use OS X system font (San Francisco) on El Capitan
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1 stable
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

`SFUIText-Light` does not work on latest OS X. Consider using `.SFNSDisplay-Light` instead.

Also, take a look at #7122 first.

data.title: Some 'font-family' properties in the workbench CSS not work as expected due to lack of quotation marks
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1 stable
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

I tried to add `'.SFNSDisplay-Light'` value into the `font-family` property since `'SFUIText-Light'` value does not work on latest OS X.
**During the building process, quotation marks / apostrophes wrapping font names are removed.** `'.SFNSDisplay-Light'` without quotation marks does not resolve to the font as expected, so Helvetica is used instead. After I add quotation marks back, it works.

data.title: Source map don't refresh after source change/save & node restart.  Attaching/re-attaching to Meteor.js server (meteor debug)
data.body:
- VSCode Version:  1.1.1
- OS Version:  Linux Mint 14 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start any meteor application via "meteor debug"
2. When node pauses, attached debugger 
       {
           "name": "Attach Server",
           "type": "node",
           "request": "attach",
           "port": 5858,
           "address": "127.0.0.1",
           "restart": true,
           "sourceMaps": true,
           "outDir": null,
           "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
           "remoteRoot": null
       },
3. The program pauses for debugging perfectly..
4. Add, remove or change any line of source or even change location of debugger statement and save.
5. detach debugger.
6. Break out of meteor instance (ctrl-c).
7. Start meteor via "meteor debug" (#1 above)
8. Attach debugger (#2 above)

ISSUE:
9. The program WILL pause at the new debugger location and correctly run the code changes, however the source map shows the source before modification (obviously making debugging impossible).  To correct and get the source map recreated/updated I need to closing VSCode and re-starting, then re-attaching the debugger.

Side Issue:  The 'F9' debug breaks don't work at all when attaching to meteor application line above, I have to use 'debugger' statements.  It'd be so much more convenient use pause with F9 breaks.. F9 works just fine when launching a straight node application, not sure what the difference is or if I'm doing something wrong?

BTW, VSCode kicks ass, thanks for building this, it's so fast and nice to work with.. I've been using Webstorm for node/meteor for years, I switched, the speed of the application is night & day (debugging is where is really hit home though (except for having to type 'debugger' all over :)).

data.title: OS X Terminal cannot open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: os x 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add User Key Binding

``` json
  { 
    "key": "ctrl+shift+t", 
    "command": "workbench.action.terminal.toggleTerminal" 
  }
```
1. Trigger

```
No handler found for the command: 'workbench.action.terminal.toggleTerminal'. An extension might be missing an activation event.
```

data.title: Offer Flatpak as Linux installation option
data.body:
Ubuntu has "click" packages:
- https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/publish/packaging-click-apps/

For everyone else (including Ubuntu):
- http://flatpak.org/

LibreOffice is now available via Flatpak:
- https://whatofhow.wordpress.com/2016/06/01/libreoffice-5-2-beta-flatpak/

Although there are some caveats:

> Flatpak-based apps are not yet able to reach out to other applications installed on the machine (like browsers) to e.g. open URLs through them. That means that e.g. clicking on a hyperlink in a LibreOffice Writer document might not work yet.

Besides being a path to having a single Linux bundle format, there are also sandbox features that might be appealing. Might be nice to know that a VSCode extension can't modify /boot, etc.

data.title: Code inline highlighting not functional inside bold or italics text
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Any (up to 1.1
- OS Version: Any (tried OSX and Win10)

seems that code inside bold or italics text is not rendered (as it is here on github even):

``` md
**te`code`st**
_te`code`st_
`code`
```

**te`code`st**
_te`code`st_
`code`

Same for **_bold italics_**

data.title: C# Resolve for usings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce: 
1. Type in a class that exists somewhere in a referenced library. 
2. Right click the class
3. Go to Resolve -> then Add using statement or replace with full namespace

This is a feature I love in Visual Studio and MonoDevelop. However I'm really enjoying vscode and would like this to be my main editor. This is a feature I adored.

data.title: Keyboard shortcut for switching between diff/editor views
data.body: There is a button in the top right of the editor which says either "Switch to Editor View" or "Switch to Changes View". Maybe I'm missing it but I can't find a keyboard shortcut for this functionality.

data.title: Consistently hitting heap limits during optimize-vscode

milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: master
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

The build server doesn't seem to be experiencing the same problem, I tried restarting and re-cloning vscode and it was the same.

```
$ gulp vscode-linux-x64-build-deb
...
[15:21:21] Starting 'optimize-vscode'...

<--- Last few GCs --->

   82576 ms: Mark-sweep 1031.1 (1434.8) -> 1030.9 (1434.8) MB, 744.4 / 0 ms [allocation failure] [GC in old space requested].
   83317 ms: Mark-sweep 1030.9 (1434.8) -> 1030.9 (1434.8) MB, 741.0 / 0 ms [allocation failure] [GC in old space requested].
   84076 ms: Mark-sweep 1030.9 (1434.8) -> 1030.9 (1434.8) MB, 758.3 / 0 ms [last resort gc].
```

data.title: Integrated terminal needs to be closed in memory not just visually.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the integrated terminal
2. Run "ng serve" which starts a process
3. Close the terminal by clicking on the right-top X
4. Open terminal again 
5. Everything is like before, I can **NOT** enter anything in the terminal.
6. How am I assumed to cancel the current process to enter something new like ng build, ng test, or any other tool?
   6.5 At the moment I have always to restart vscode :/
7. WebStorm has a red square button for that feature :-)

data.title: Marketplace is bad at detecting licenses
data.body:
Prime examples:
- https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items/donjayamanne.python/license
- https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items/donjayamanne.javadebugger/license

It seems to do with non-SPDX identifiers in the license field of package.json, however when a valid SPDX identifier exists [it just dumps](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items/Tyriar.sort-lines/license) the [contents of `LICENSE`](https://github.com/Tyriar/vscode-sort-lines/blob/master/LICENSE) on the webpage. Why not just always do that...?

data.title: Window Crashing very often

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Yosemite

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Try to work on code
2. Arbitrary crash, window saying that the window has crashed and sorry for the inconvenience

This is completely unacceptable: having crashes in a developer product this often.
